dialogs.original: So now prosperity begins to mellow    And drop into the rotten mouth of death.    Here in these confines slyly have I lurked    To watch the waning of mine enemies.    A dire induction am I witness to,    And will to France, hoping the consequence    Will prove as bitter, black, and tragical.    Withdraw thee, wretched Margaret. Who comes here?
dialogs.translated: So now the Yorks' prosperity has ripened and rotted, falling into the mouth of death. I've been lurking in the shadows here to watch my enemies come to ruin, and it's a terrible scene I've witnessedan ominous prologue to what I hope will be a bitter, dark, and tragic conclusion. I'll head to France. But hide now, wretched Margaret. Who's coming?

dialogs.original: Ah, my poor princes! Ah, my tender babes,    My unblown flowers, new-appearing sweets,    If yet your gentle souls fly in the air    And be not fixed in doom perpetual,    Hover about me with your airy wings    And hear your mothers lamentation.
dialogs.translated: Ah, my poor princes! Ah, my tender babesmy flowers who didn't have a chance to bloom! If your gentle souls are still flying about in the air and haven't yet landed in their final resting place, then hover about me now with your airy wings, and hear your mother's cries of mourning.

dialogs.original: [aside]  Hover about her; say that right for rightHath dimmed your infant morn to agèd night.
dialogs.translated: [To herself] Hover about her, spirits, and say that she got what she deserved, since you were also killed before your time.

dialogs.original: So many miseries have crazed my voiceThat my woe-wearied tongue is still and mute.Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead?
dialogs.translated: So many miseries have cracked my voice that my tongue is weary of wailing and has gone silent. Edward Plantagenet, why are you dead?

dialogs.original: [aside]  Plantagenet doth quit Plantagenet;Edward for Edward pays a dying debt.
dialogs.translated: [To herself] One Plantagenet makes up for another. Edward dies to pay the debt for another Edward's death.

dialogs.original: Wilt thou, O God, fly from such gentle lambsAnd throw them in the entrails of the wolf?When didst thou sleep when such a deed was done?
dialogs.translated: Oh God, will you abandon such gentle lambs, and throw them to the wolf? How could you sleep when such a deed was done?

dialogs.original: [aside]  When holy Harry died, and my sweet son.
dialogs.translated: [To herself] God slept when my holy husband Henry died, and my sweet son Edward.

dialogs.original: [sitting down]     Dead life, blind sight, poor mortal living ghost,    Woes scene, worlds shame, graves due by life usurped,    Brief abstract and record of tedious days,    Rest thy unrest on Englands lawful earth,    Unlawfully made drunk with innocent blood.
dialogs.translated: [Sitting down] My life has died. My sight has gone blind. I'm like a ghost that's still alive. I am the bearer of misfortune; the shame of the world; a soul that rightfully belongs to the grave. As a summary and brief record of my unbearable life, I will rest my restless bones on England's lawful earth, which is now covered with innocent blood, against the laws of man and nature.

dialogs.original: [sitting down beside her]     Ah, that thou wouldst as soon afford a grave    As thou canst yield a melancholy seat,    Then would I hide my bones, not rest them here.    O, who hath any cause to mourn but we?
dialogs.translated: [Sitting down beside her] Ah, if only the earth could provide me with a grave instead of just a sad seat, then I would bury my bones, instead of simply resting them here. Oh, who has any right to mourn except for us?

dialogs.original: [joining them]    If ancient sorrow be most reverend,    Give mine the benefit of seigniory,    And let my griefs frown on the upper hand.    If sorrow can admit society,    Tell o'er your woes again by viewing mine.    I had an Edward till a Richard killed him;    I had a husband till a Richard killed him.    Thou hadst an Edward till a Richard killed him;    Thou hadst a Richard till a Richard killed him.
dialogs.translated: [Joining them and sitting] If the oldest sorrow is the most revered, then give mine the privilege of seniority, and let my grief have the upper hand. If you can accept company in your sadness, then consider your losses again by looking at mine. I had an Edward until a Richard killed him. And I had a husband, Henry, until a Richard killed him. You had an Edward until a Richard killed him, and you had a Richard, young York, until a Richard killed him.

dialogs.original: I had a Richard too, and thou didst kill him; I had a Rutland too; thou holpst to kill him.
dialogs.translated: I had a Richard too, my husband, and you killed him. I had a Rutland too, and you helped to kill him.

dialogs.original: Thou hadst a Clarence too, and Richard killed him    Then forth the kennel of thy womb hath crept    A hellhound that doth hunt us all to death    That dog, that had his teeth before his eyes,    To worry lambs and lap their gentle blood;    That excellent grand tyrant of the earth,    That reigns in gallèd eyes of weeping souls;    That foul defacer of Gods handiwork    Thy womb let loose to chase us to our graves.    O upright, just, and true-disposing God,    How do I thank thee that this carnal cur    Preys on the issue of his mothers body    And makes her pew-fellow with others' moan!
dialogs.translated: You had a Clarence too, and Richard killed him. The kennel of your womb has let loose a hellhound that hunts us all to deatha dog that had teeth before it had eyes. His teeth attack lambs and lap up their gentle blood. He is the greatest tyrant of the earth, and thrives among the tears of those he has injured. That foul creature who defaces God's handiwork came forth from your womb to chase us to our graves. Oh, upright, just, and generous God, how can I thank you enough that this deadly mutt preys on his mother's offspring and makes her a companion to others' sorrow?

dialogs.original: O Harrys wife, triumph not in my woes! God witness with me, I have wept for thine.
dialogs.translated: Oh, Henry's wife, do not triumph in my woes! As God is my witness, I have wept for yours.

dialogs.original: Bear with me, I am hungry for revenge,    And now I cloy me with beholding it.    Thy Edward he is dead, that killed my Edward,    Thy other Edward dead, to quit my Edward;    Young York, he is but boot, because both they    Matched not the high perfection of my loss.    Thy Clarence he is dead that stabbed my Edward,    And the beholders of this frantic play,    Th' adulterate Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey,    Untimely smothered in their dusky graves.    Richard yet lives, hells black intelligencer,    Only reserved their factor to buy souls    And send them thither.   But at hand, at hand    Ensues his piteous and unpitied end.    Earth gapes, hell burns, fiends roar, saints pray,    To have him suddenly conveyed from hence.    Cancel his bond of life, dear God I pray,    That I may live to say, The dog is dead.
dialogs.translated: Bear with me. I am hungry for revenge, and now I'm almost sick from gorging myself upon it. Your son Edwardwho killed my son Edwardis dead. Your grandson Edward is also dead, with young York thrown in as an extra, because both your grandsons didn't equal my lost son. Your Clarencewho stabbed my son Edwardis dead. And the audience to this frantic playthe adulterer Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, and Greyhave all been smothered in early graves. Richard still lives as hell's dark spy, only allowed to remain long enough to buy souls and send them down below. But soon, soon his pitiful and well-deserved end will come. The earth gapes open, hell burns, devils roar, and saints pray that he might be quickly sent from this earth. Dear God, end his life soon, so that I may live to say, "The dog is dead!"

dialogs.original: O, thou didst prophesy the time would come That I should wish for thee to help me curseThat bottled spider, that foul bunch-backed toad!
dialogs.translated: Oh, you once did prophesy that the time would come when I would want your help in cursing that swollen spider, that foul hunchbacked toad!

dialogs.original: I called thee then vain flourish of my fortune.    I called thee then poor shadow, painted queen,    The presentation of but what I was,    The flattering index of a direful pageant,    One heaved a-high, to be hurled down below,    A mother only mocked with two fair babes,    A dream of what thou wast, a garish flag    To be the aim of every dangerous shot,    A sign of dignity, a breath, a bubble,    A queen in jest, only to fill the scene.    Where is thy husband now? Where be thy brothers?    Where are thy two sons? Wherein dost thou joy?    Who sues and kneels and says God save the queen?    Where be the bending peers that flattered thee?    Where be the thronging troops that followed thee?    Decline all this, and see what now thou art:    For happy wife, a most distressèd widow;    For joyful mother, one that wails the name;    For queen, a very caitiff crowned with care;    For one being sued to, one that humbly sues;    For she that scorned at me, now scorned of me;    For she being feared of all, now fearing one;    For she commanding all, obeyed of none.    Thus hath the course of justice whirled about    And left thee but a very prey to time,    Having no more but thought of what thou wast    To torture thee the more, being what thou art.    Thou didst usurp my place, and dost thou not    Usurp the just proportion of my sorrow?    Now thy proud neck bears half my burdened yoke,    From which even here I slip my weary head    And leave the burthen of it all on thee.    Farewell, Yorks wife, and queen of sad mischance.    These English woes will make me smile in France.
dialogs.translated: And then I called you a "poor imitation of a queen" and a "meaningless decoration on my throne"the image of what I was in realitythe pretty prologue to an ominous tragedy; a woman lifted high only to be hurled down below; a mother mocked with the gifts of two dear babies, only to lose them. You were a shadow of a queen; a gaudy banner that enemies could target; an empty symbol of dignity; a breath; a bubble; a mockery of a queen; a stand-in only there to fill the role. And where is your husband now? Where are your brothers? Where are your two sons? Where do you find your joy? Who kneels before you and makes requests and says, "God save the queen?" Where are the bowing noblemen who flattered you? Where are the crowds that followed you? Without all this, see what you are: instead of a happy wife, a grieving widow; instead of a joyful mother, a woman who wails over her children; instead of a queen, a poor wretch crowned only with worries; instead of one granting favors, one humbly begging for favors. She who mocked me is now mocked by me, and she who commanded everyone is now obeyed by no one. See how the wheel of justice has turned, leaving you the victim of time. All you have left are the memories of your former glory, which torture you even more when you consider what you've become. You usurped my position, and now see how you usurp my sorrow. Your proud neck bears half of my heavy burden, but now let me give it all to you. Farewell, York's wife, queen of sad misfortune. These English woes will make me smile in France.

dialogs.original: O, thou well-skilled in curses, stay awhile,And teach me how to curse mine enemies.
dialogs.translated: Oh, you who are so skilled in curses, stay a while and teach me how to curse my enemies.

dialogs.original: Forbear to sleep the nights, and fast the days;    Compare dead happiness with living woe;    Think that thy babes were sweeter than they were,    And he that slew them fouler than he is.  Bettering thy loss makes the bad causer worse.Revolving this will teach thee how to curse.
dialogs.translated: Don't sleep at night, and don't eat during the day. Compare lost happiness with current suffering. Remember your children as being sweeter than they were, and think of the one that killed them as fouler than he is. Magnifying your grief makes the person who caused it even worse. Doing all this will teach you how to curse.

dialogs.original: My words are dull. O, quicken them with thine!
dialogs.translated: My words are dull. Oh, give them life with yours!

dialogs.original: Thy woes will make them sharp and pierce like mine.
dialogs.translated: Your suffering will make them sharp, so they can pierce like mine.

dialogs.original: Why should calamity be full of words?
dialogs.translated: Why should this catastrophe be accompanied by so many words?

dialogs.original: Windy attorneys to their clients' woes,    Airy succeeders of intestate joys,    Poor breathing orators of miseries,    Let them have scope, though what they will impart    Help nothing else, yet do they ease the heart.
dialogs.translated: Words are useless breath, like lawyers pleading on their sad clients' behalf; like the children of joys who inherit nothing; like poor speech-makers going on about misery. Even so, let them have a chance. Though they won't help in any other way, they still help ease the heart.

dialogs.original: If so, then be not tongue-tied. Go with me,And in the breath of bitter words lets smotherMy damnèd son that thy two sweet sons smothered.
dialogs.translated: If that's so, then don't be tongue-tied. Come with me, and with our bitter words let's smother my damned son Richard who smothered your two sons.

dialogs.original: The trumpet sounds. Be copious in exclaims.
dialogs.translated: The trumpet soundshe's coming. Don't restrain yourself.

dialogs.original: Who intercepts my expedition?
dialogs.translated: Who's blocking my path?

dialogs.original: O, she that might have intercepted thee,By strangling thee in her accursèd womb,From all the slaughters, wretch, that thou hast done.
dialogs.translated: Oh, you wretch! It is she who could have blocked you from all the murders you've committedby strangling you in her cursed womb.

dialogs.original: Hidst thou that forehead with a golden crown    Where should be branded, if that right were right,    The slaughter of the prince that owed that crown    And the dire death of my poor sons and brothers?    Tell me, thou villain-slave, where are my children?
dialogs.translated: Are you hiding that forehead with a golden crown, when, if the world was just, it would be branded with the mark of your crimesthe slaughter of the prince who rightfully possessed that crown, and the monstrous deaths of my poor sons and brothers? Tell me, you low-born criminal, where are my children?

dialogs.original: Thou toad, thou toad, where is thy brother Clarence?And little Ned Plantagenet his son?
dialogs.translated: You toad, you toad, where is your brother Clarence? And little Ned Plantagenet, his son.

dialogs.original: Where is gentle Rivers, Vaughan, Grey?
dialogs.translated: Where is noble Rivers, and Vaughan, and Grey?

dialogs.original: Where is kind Hastings?
dialogs.translated: Where is kind Hastings?

dialogs.original: A flourish, trumpets! Strike alarum, drums! Let not the heavens hear these telltale womenRail on the Lords anointed. Strike, I say!
dialogs.translated: Trumpets, play! Drums, a call to arms! Don't let the heavens hear these tattle-tale women abuse the Lord's anointed king. Play, I say!

dialogs.original: Either be patient and entreat me fair,Or with the clamorous report of warThus will I drown your exclamations.
dialogs.translated: Either be patient and treat me with courtesy or I'll drown you out with the noisy music of war.

dialogs.original: Art thou my son?
dialogs.translated: Are you my son?

dialogs.original: Ay, I thank God, my father, and yourself.
dialogs.translated: Yes, and for that I thank God, my father, and yourself.

dialogs.original: Then patiently hear my impatience.
dialogs.translated: Then patiently listen to my impatience.

dialogs.original: Madam, I have a touch of your condition,Which cannot brook the accent of reproof.
dialogs.translated: Madam, I have some of your temperament, in that I can't tolerate the language of disapproval.

dialogs.original: O, let me speak!
dialogs.translated: Oh, let me speak!

dialogs.original: Do then, but Ill not hear.
dialogs.translated: Speak then, but I won't listen.

dialogs.original: I will be mild and gentle in my words.
dialogs.translated: I will be mild and gentle in my words.

dialogs.original: And brief, good mother, for I am in haste.
dialogs.translated: And be brief too, good mother, for I'm in a hurry.

dialogs.original: Art thou so hasty? I have stayed for thee,God knows, in torment and in agony.
dialogs.translated: Are you so impatient? God knows I waited for you, in torment and in agony, when I was giving birth to you.

dialogs.original: And came I not at last to comfort you?
dialogs.translated: And didn't I come at last to comfort you?

dialogs.original: No, by the Holy Rood, thou knowst it well.    Thou camst on earth to make the earth my hell.    A grievous burden was thy birth to me;    Tetchy and wayward was thy infancy;    Thy school days frightful, desp'rate, wild, and furious;    Thy prime of manhood daring, bold, and venturous;    Thy age confirmed, proud, subtle, sly, and bloody,    More mild, but yet more harmful, kind in hatred.    What comfortable hour canst thou name,    That ever graced me in thy company?
dialogs.translated: No, by the Holy Cross, and you know it well. You came to earth to make the earth my hell. Your birth was a painful burden to me. You were fussy and willful as a baby. Your school days were frightening, wild, and angry. As a young man, you were daring, bold, and adventurous. And in your maturity you've grown proud, cunning, sly, and bloodyless wild but more dangerous, flattering in your hatred. Can you name a comfortable hour I've ever had in your company?

dialogs.original: Faith, none but Humfrey Hower, that called your Grace    To breakfast once, forth of my company.    If I be so disgracious in your eye,    Let me march on and not offend you, madam.    Strike up the drum.
dialogs.translated: Well, none but Humphrey Hour, who once invited you to have breakfast without my company. If I'm so displeasing to look at, then let me march on and not offend you, madam.

dialogs.original: I prithee, hear me speak.
dialogs.translated: Please, listen to me speak.

dialogs.original: You speak too bitterly.
dialogs.translated: You speak too bitterly.

dialogs.original: Hear me a word,For I shall never speak to thee again.
dialogs.translated: Just listen a moment, and then I'll never speak to you again.

dialogs.original: So.
dialogs.translated: Then do it.

dialogs.original: Either thou wilt die by Gods just ordinance    Ere from this war thou turn a conqueror,    Or I with grief and extreme age shall perish    And nevermore behold thy face again.    Therefore take with thee my most grievous curse,    Which in the day of battle tire thee more    Than all the complete armor that thou wearst.    My prayers on the adverse party fight,    And there the little souls of Edwards children    Whisper the spirits of thine enemies    And promise them success and victory.    Bloody thou art; bloody will be thy end.    Shame serves thy life and doth thy death attend.
dialogs.translated: Either you'll dieas God's just punishmentbefore you can return victorious from this war, or else I will die from grief and old age. At any rate, I'll never see your face again. So take with you my most terrible curse, and may it weigh you down in battle more than your suit of armor. My prayers will fight on your enemies' side. And the little souls of Edward's children will encourage your enemies, promising them success and victory. You have lived in violence, and now you will die with violence. Your life has been shameful, so let your death be as well.

dialogs.original: Though far more cause, yet much less spirit to curseAbides in me. I say amen to her.
dialogs.translated: Though I have far more reason to curse you, I don't have her energy. I'll just say "amen" to everything she said.

dialogs.original: Stay, madam. I must talk a word with you.
dialogs.translated: Wait, madam. I must speak with you.

dialogs.original: I have no more sons of the royal blood    For thee to slaughter.   For my daughters, Richard,    They shall be praying nuns, not weeping queens,    And therefore level not to hit their lives.
dialogs.translated: I have no more sons of royal blood for you to murder. And as for my daughters, Richard, they'll become praying nuns, not weeping queens. So don't aim to destroy their lives.

dialogs.original: You have a daughter called Elizabeth, Virtuous and fair, royal and gracious.
dialogs.translated: You have a daughter called Elizabeth, who is virtuous and beautiful, royal and gracious.

dialogs.original: And must she die for this? O, let her live,    And Ill corrupt her manners, stain her beauty,    Slander myself as false to Edwards bed,    Throw over her the veil of infamy.    So she may live unscarred of bleeding slaughter,    I will confess she was not Edwards daughter.
dialogs.translated: And must she die for this? Oh, let her live, and I'll ruin her manner, mar her beauty, lie and say she is illegitimate, and destroy her reputation. So that she might escape being murdered, I'll say that she was not Edward's daughter.

dialogs.original: Wrong not her birth. She is a royal princess.
dialogs.translated: Don't lie about her birth. She is a royal princess.

dialogs.original: To save her life, Ill say she is not so.
dialogs.translated: To save her life, I'll say she isn't.

dialogs.original: Her life is safest only in her birth.
dialogs.translated: Her royal birth is what makes her safest.

dialogs.original: And only in that safety died her brothers.
dialogs.translated: Her brothers died because of that same "safety."

dialogs.original: Lo, at their births good stars were opposite.
dialogs.translated: Alas, at birth they were badly fated.

dialogs.original: No, to their lives ill friends were contrary.
dialogs.translated: No, in their lives they were opposed by bad friends.

dialogs.original: All unavoided is the doom of destiny.
dialogs.translated: No one can avoid the doom of destiny.

dialogs.original: True, when avoided grace makes destiny. My babes were destined to a fairer deathIf grace had blessed thee with a fairer life.
dialogs.translated: That's true, when someone who has avoided God's grace is controlling that destiny. My children would have been destined to better deaths if you had been blessed with a more virtuous life.

dialogs.original: You speak as if that I had slain my cousins.
dialogs.translated: You speak as if I had killed my nephews.

dialogs.original: Cousins, indeed, and by their uncle cozened    Of comfort, kingdom, kindred, freedom, life.    Whose hand soever launched their tender hearts,    Thy head, all indirectly, gave direction.    No doubt the murd'rous knife was dull and blunt    Till it was whetted on thy stone-hard heart,    To revel in the entrails of my lambs.    But that still use of grief makes wild grief tame,    My tongue should to thy ears not name my boys    Till that my nails were anchored in thine eyes,    And I, in such a desp'rate bay of death,    Like a poor bark of sails and tackling reft,    Rush all to pieces on thy rocky bosom.
dialogs.translated: Indeed, your nephews were cheated by their uncle of their comfort, kingdom, relatives, freedom, and life. Some other hand might have pierced their tender hearts, but you're the one who gave the order. No doubt the murderous knife was dull and blunt until it was sharpened against your hard heart of stone, and after that it could rejoice among my little lambs' bloody innards. But constant talk of grief makes wild grief tame, so I won't say my boys' names again until I've anchored my fingernails in your eyes and gouged them out. I am like a poor boat without sails in a stormy bay of death, and I'll break myself to pieces against your rocky heart.

dialogs.original: Madam, so thrive I in my enterprise    And dangerous success of bloody wars    As I intend more good to you and yours    Than ever you or yours were by me harmed!
dialogs.translated: Madam, if I am successful in these dangerous, bloody wars to which I am marching off, I then intend to do more good to you and your relatives than I've ever done them harm!

dialogs.original: What good is covered with the face of heaven,To be discovered, that can do me good?
dialogs.translated: What good is there still undiscovered in this world that can do me good now?

dialogs.original: The advancement of your children, gentle lady.
dialogs.translated: The advancement of your children, noble lady.

dialogs.original: Up to some scaffold, there to lose their heads.
dialogs.translated: Advancing them up to some scaffold, to lose their heads.

dialogs.original: Unto the dignity and height of fortune, The high imperial type of this earths glory.
dialogs.translated: Advancement to the dignity and height of fortune, the most kingly symbol of this world's glory.

dialogs.original: Flatter my sorrow with report of it.Tell me what state, what dignity, what honor,Canst thou demise to any child of mine?
dialogs.translated: Flatter me in my sorrow then. Tell me what rank, what dignity, or what honor you could possibly offer to any child of mine?

dialogs.original: Even all I have ay, and myself and all    Will I withal endow a child of thine;    So in the Lethe of thy angry soul    Thou drown the sad remembrance of those wrongs    Which thou supposest I have done to thee.
dialogs.translated: Only everything I haveyes, including myself. That's what I'll give to a child of yours. May Lethe drown your sad memories of the wrongs you imagine I've done to you.

dialogs.original: Be brief, lest that the process of thy kindness Last longer telling than thy kindness' date.
dialogs.translated: Explain yourself quickly, before this speech about your kindness outlasts whatever kindness you have.

dialogs.original: Then know that from my soul I love thy daughter.
dialogs.translated: Then know that from my soul I love your daughter Elizabeth.

dialogs.original: My daughters mother thinks it with her soul.
dialogs.translated: And I believe it with my soul.

dialogs.original: What do you think?
dialogs.translated: What do you believe?

dialogs.original: That thou dost love my daughter from thy soul. So from thy souls love didst thou love her brothers,And from my hearts love I do thank thee for it.
dialogs.translated: That you love my daughter from your soulfar from your soul. Just like you loved her brothers. And from my heart's same love I thank you for it.

dialogs.original: Be not so hasty to confound my meaning.I mean that with my soul I love thy daughterAnd do intend to make her Queen of England.
dialogs.translated: Don't be so quick to confuse my meaning. I mean that I love your daughter with my soul, and I intend to make her Queen of England.

dialogs.original: Well then, who dost thou mean shall be her king?
dialogs.translated: Well then, who will be her king?

dialogs.original: Even he that makes her queen. Who else should be?
dialogs.translated: The same man who makes her queen. Who else should it be?

dialogs.original: What, thou?
dialogs.translated: What, you?

dialogs.original: Even so. How think you of it?
dialogs.translated: Of course. What did you think?

dialogs.original: How canst thou woo her?
dialogs.translated: How would you go about wooing her?

dialogs.original: That would I learn of you,As one being best acquainted with her humor.
dialogs.translated: That's what I want to learn from you, since you know her temperament best.

dialogs.original: And wilt thou learn of me?
dialogs.translated: And will you learn from me?

dialogs.original: Madam, with all my heart.
dialogs.translated: Madam, with all my heart.

dialogs.original: Send to her, by the man that slew her brothers,    A pair of bleeding hearts; thereon engrave    Edward and York. Then haply she will weep.    Therefore present to heras sometime Margaret    Did to thy father, steeped in Rutlands blood    A handkerchief, which say to her did drain    The purple sap from her sweet brothers body,    And bid her wipe her weeping eyes withal.    If this inducement move her not to love,    Send her a letter of thy noble deeds;    Tell her thou madst away her uncle Clarence,    Her uncle Rivers, ay, and for her sake    Madst quick conveyance with her good aunt Anne.
dialogs.translated: Then send to herfrom the man who killed her brothersa pair of bleeding hearts. Write "Edward" and "York" on them. Then she might weep. So to wipe up her tears, present her with a handkerchieflike the one Margaret gave to your father, steeped in his son Rutland's bloodand tell her that this handkerchief wiped up the blood that drained from her sweet brother's body. Tell her to wipe her weeping eyes with it. If all this doesn't convince her to love you, then send her a letter describing your other noble deeds. Tell her that you secretly killed her uncle Clarence, her uncle Rivers, yes, and speedily killed her good aunt Anne for her sake.

dialogs.original: You mock me, madam. This is not the wayTo win your daughter.
dialogs.translated: You mock me, madam. This is not the way to win your daughter.

dialogs.original: There is no other way,Unless thou couldst put on some other shape And not be Richard, that hath done all this.
dialogs.translated: There is no other way, unless you could change your shape and be someone other than the Richard who has committed all these deeds.

dialogs.original: Say that I did all this for love of her.
dialogs.translated: Say that I did all those things out of love for her.

dialogs.original: Nay, then indeed she cannot choose but hate thee,Having bought love with such a bloody spoil.
dialogs.translated: No, for then she has no choice but to hate you, as you tried to buy her love with murder.

dialogs.original: Look what is done cannot be now amended.    Men shall deal unadvisedly sometimes,    Which after-hours give leisure to repent.    If I did take the kingdom from your sons,    To make amends Ill give it to your daughter.    If I have killed the issue of your womb,    To quicken your increase I will beget    Mine issue of your blood upon your daughter.    A grandams name is little less in love    Than is the doting title of a mother.    They are as children but one step below,    Even of your metal, of your very blood,    Of all one pain, save for a night of groans    Endured of her for whom you bid like sorrow.    Your children were vexation to your youth,    But mine shall be a comfort to your age.    The loss you have is but a son being king,    And by that loss your daughter is made queen.    I cannot make you what amends I would;    Therefore accept such kindness as I can.    Dorset your son, that with a fearful soul    Leads discontented steps in foreign soil,    This fair alliance quickly shall call home    To high promotions and great dignity.    The king that calls your beauteous daughter wife    Familiarly shall call thy Dorset brother.    Again shall you be mother to a king,    And all the ruins of distressful times    Repaired with double riches of content.    What, we have many goodly days to see!    The liquid drops of tears that you have shed    Shall come again, transformed to orient pearl,    Advantaging their love with interest    Of ten times double gain of happiness.    Go then, my mother; to thy daughter go.    Make bold her bashful years with your experience;    Prepare her ears to hear a wooers tale;    Put in her tender heart th' aspiring flame    Of golden sovereignty; acquaint the Princess    With the sweet silent hours of marriage joys;    And when this arm of mine hath chastisèd    The petty rebel, dull-brained Buckingham,    Bound with triumphant garlands will I come    And lead thy daughter to a conquerors bed,    To whom I will retail my conquest won,    And she shall be sole victoress, Caesars Caesar.
dialogs.translated: Whatever is done cannot be undone. Men make mistakes sometimes, and then they repent when they have the time. If I did take the kingdom from your sons, then to make up for it I'll give it to your daughter. If I've killed your children, then I'll give them new life by having children with your daughter. A grandmother is hardly loved less than a mother. Grandchildren are just one step removed from children, made of your same substance and your very blood. They take the same amount of effort, minus that one night of labor which you suffered for your daughter's sake. Your children troubled you in your youth, but my children will comfort you in your old age. Your only real loss is that your son wasn't king, but through that loss your daughter will become queen. I can't repay you as much as I'd like to, so accept what kindness I can offer. Your son Dorsetwho fled in fear and joined the French army against mewould come quickly home to high promotions and great dignity if this marriage takes place. The king who calls your beautiful daughter "wife" will call Dorset "brother." Once again you'll be the mother to a king, and all the ruins of unhappy times will be repaired with double their value in contentment. Why, we can look forward to many good days ahead! The liquid tears you've shed will return, transformed into pearls. Your happiness will increase to ten times its original size, plus interest. Go then, my future mother-in-law; go to your daughter. Use your experience to make her bold in her youthful innocence. Prepare her ears to hear my courting words. Put in her tender heart the ambition to be queen. Acquaint the Princess with the sweet, silent hours of joy in marriage, and when I've punished that petty rebel, dull-brained Buckingham, I will return crowned with victory wreaths and lead your daughter to a conquerer's bed. I will transmit all my victory to her, and she will be the  real conquerorthe emperor of the emperor.

dialogs.original: What were I best to say? Her fathers brother    Would be her lord? Or shall I say her uncle?    Or he that slew her brothers and her uncles?    Under what title shall I woo for thee,    That God, the law, my honor and her love    Can make seem pleasing to her tender years?
dialogs.translated: What should I say to her? Her father's brother wants to be her husband? Or should I say it's her uncle? Or should I say it's the man who killed her brothers and uncles? Under what name should I go wooing on your behalf? What name can please God, the law, and my honor, and also seem appealing to such a young woman?

dialogs.original: Infer fair Englands peace by this alliance.
dialogs.translated: Imply that fair England's peace depends on this marriage.

dialogs.original: Which she shall purchase with still-lasting war.
dialogs.translated: So she will purchase that peace with everlasting war.

dialogs.original: Tell her the king, that may command, entreats
dialogs.translated: Tell her that the King, who has the power to command, instead begs her

dialogs.original: That, at her hands, which the kings King forbids.
dialogs.translated: Begs her to do what God, the King of Kings, forbidsmarriage between an uncle and a niece.

dialogs.original: Say she shall be a high and mighty queen.
dialogs.translated: Say that she will be a high and mighty queen.

dialogs.original: To vail the title, as her mother doth.
dialogs.translated: Only so that she can give up that title, as her mother has.

dialogs.original: Say I will love her everlastingly.
dialogs.translated: Say I will love her forever.

dialogs.original: But how long shall that title ever last?
dialogs.translated: But how long will that "ever" last?

dialogs.original: Sweetly in force unto her fair lifes end.
dialogs.translated: For as long as her fair life lasts.

dialogs.original: But how long fairly shall her sweet life last?
dialogs.translated: But how long will her sweet life last?

dialogs.original: As long as heaven and nature lengthens it.
dialogs.translated: As long as heaven and nature lengthen it.

dialogs.original: As long as hell and Richard likes of it.
dialogs.translated: As long as hell and Richard decide.

dialogs.original: Say I, her sovereign, am her subject low.
dialogs.translated: Say that I, her king, am her lowly subject.

dialogs.original: But she, your subject, loathes such sovereignty.
dialogs.translated: But she, your actual subject, hates such a king.

dialogs.original: Be eloquent in my behalf to her.
dialogs.translated: Speak well of me to her.

dialogs.original: An honest tale speeds best being plainly told.
dialogs.translated: An honest tale works best when it's told plainly.

dialogs.original: Then plainly to her tell my loving tale.
dialogs.translated: Then plainly tell her my loving tale.

dialogs.original: Plain and not honest is too harsh a style.
dialogs.translated: Plain and not honest is too harsh to hear. Lies need some decoration.

dialogs.original: Your reasons are too shallow and too quick.
dialogs.translated: Your answers are too shallow and too lively.

dialogs.original: O no, my reasons are too deep and deadToo deep and dead, poor infants, in their graves.
dialogs.translated: Oh no, my reasons are too deep and too deadtoo deep and too dead, just like my poor infants in their graves.

dialogs.original: Harp not on that string, madam; that is past.
dialogs.translated: Don't harp on that string, madamthat's in the past.

dialogs.original: Harp on it still shall I till heart-strings break.
dialogs.translated: I'll harp on it until my heartstrings break.

dialogs.original: Now by my George, my Garter, and my crown
dialogs.translated: Now, by my Saint George, my garter, and my crown

dialogs.original: Profaned, dishonored, and the third usurped.
dialogs.translated: The first one profaned, the second dishonored, and the third stolen.

dialogs.original: I swear
dialogs.translated: I swear

dialogs.original: By nothing, for this is no oath.    Thy George, profaned, hath lost his lordly honor;    Thy garter, blemished, pawned his knightly virtue;    Thy crown, usurped, disgraced his kingly glory.    If something thou wouldst swear to be believed,    Swear then by something that thou hast not wronged.
dialogs.translated: By nothingbecause this is no proper oath. Your Saint George, profaned by you, has lost his lordly honor. Your garter, stained by you, has lost its knightly virtue. Your crown, stolen by you, has disgraced its kingly glory. If you want to swear by something that I might believe in, then swear by something that you haven't wronged.

dialogs.original: Then, by myself
dialogs.translated: Then I swear by myself

dialogs.original: Thyself is self-misused.
dialogs.translated: You've misused yourself.

dialogs.original: Now, by the world
dialogs.translated: By the world then

dialogs.original: 'Tis full of thy foul wrongs.
dialogs.translated: It's full of your foul crimes.

dialogs.original: My fathers death
dialogs.translated: By my father's death

dialogs.original: Thy life hath it dishonored.
dialogs.translated: Your life has dishonored his death.

dialogs.original: Why then, by God.
dialogs.translated: Why then, by God.

dialogs.original: Gods wrong is most of all.    If thou didst fear to break an oath by Him,    The unity the king my husband made    Thou hadst not broken, nor my brothers died.    If thou hadst feared to break an oath by Him,    Th' imperial metal circling now thy head    Had graced the tender temples of my child,    And both the princes had been breathing here,    Which now, two tender bedfellows for dust,    Thy broken faith hath made the prey for worms.    What canst thou swear by now?
dialogs.translated: You've abused God most of all. If you really feared to break an oath sworn by God, you never would have broken the oath of friendship and unity we made to the king my husband before he diedand my brothers wouldn't have been killed. If you really feared to break an oath sworn by God, then the crown you now wear would instead be gracing the tender head of my childand both the princes would still be alive. Your broken oaths have resulted in many corpses, and much food for the worms. What can you swear by now?

dialogs.original: The time to come.
dialogs.translated: By the future.

dialogs.original: That thou hast wrongèd in the time o'erpast;    For I myself have many tears to wash    Hereafter time, for time past wronged by thee.    The children live whose fathers thou hast slaughtered,    Ungoverned youth, to wail it in their age;    The parents live whose children thou hast butchered,    Old barren plants, to wail it with their age.    Swear not by time to come, for that thou hast    Misused ere used, by times ill-used o'erpast.
dialogs.translated: You've already wronged that with your past actions. I myself have many tears left to cry in the future because of your past crimes. The children whose fathers you slaughtered are still alive, and they will grow up without guidance, unfortunate in their adulthood. The parents whose children you butchered are still alive too, old barren plants who will be miserable in their old age. Don't swear by the future, for with your past you've already ruined it.

dialogs.original: As I intend to prosper and repent,    So thrive I in my dangerous affairs    Of hostile arms!   Myself myself confound,    Heaven and fortune bar me happy hours,    Day, yield me not thy light, nor night thy rest,    Be opposite all planets of good luck    To my proceedings if, with dear hearts love,    Immaculate devotion, holy thoughts,    I tender not thy beauteous princely daughter.    In her consists my happiness and thine.    Without her follows to myself and thee,    Herself, the land, and many a Christian soul,    Death, desolation, ruin and decay.    It cannot be avoided but by this;    It will not be avoided but by this.    Therefore, dear motherI must call you so    Be the attorney of my love to her:    Plead what I will be, not what I have been;    Not my deserts, but what I will deserve.    Urge the necessity and state of times,    And be not peevish found in great designs.
dialogs.translated: May I succeed in my dangerous battles to the same degree that I truly intend to repent and prosper! May I ruin myself; be deprived of happiness by heaven and destiny; my days be dark; my nights sleepless; and my luck be bad if I don't love your beautiful, royal daughter with dear affection, pure devotion, and holy thoughts. Both my happiness and yours depends on her. Without her as my queen, death, desolation, ruin, and decay will fall on me, you, your daughter, the land, and many a Christian soul. It cannot be avoided except by this marriage. It will not be avoided except by this marriage. Therefore, dear mother-in-lawfor I must call you that nowbe my advocate, pleading on my behalf to her. Describe what I will be, not what I have been. Don't mention what I deserve now, but what I will deserve. Remind her of how necessary this marriage is for the good of the country right now, and tell her not to be foolishly willful about such an important decision.

dialogs.original: Shall I be tempted of the devil thus?
dialogs.translated: Will I let myself be tempted by the devil like this?

dialogs.original: Ay, if the devil tempt you to do good.
dialogs.translated: Yes, if the devil tempts you to do good.

dialogs.original: Shall I forget myself to be myself?
dialogs.translated: Will I forget to be who I am?

dialogs.original: Ay, if your selfs remembrance wrong yourself.
dialogs.translated: Yes, if your memories of yourself only hurt you.

dialogs.original: Yet thou didst kill my children.
dialogs.translated: But you killed my children.

dialogs.original: But in your daughters womb I bury them,Where, in that nest of spicery, they will breedSelves of themselves, to your recomforture.
dialogs.translated: But I will bury them in your daughter's womb, and in that nest of fragrant spices they will be reborn again, to grow and comfort you.

dialogs.original: Shall I go win my daughter to thy will?
dialogs.translated: Will I really go win my daughter over for you?

dialogs.original: And be a happy mother by the deed.
dialogs.translated: And make yoursel a happy mother by doing so.

dialogs.original: I go. Write to me very shortly,And you shall understand from me her mind.
dialogs.translated: I'll go. Write to me very soon, and I'll tell you how she feels.

dialogs.original: Bear her my true loves kiss; and so, farewell.
dialogs.translated: Give her my true love's kiss. And so, farewell.

dialogs.original: Relenting fool and shallow, changing woman!
dialogs.translated: Weak fool! Shallow, fickle woman!

dialogs.original: How now, what news?
dialogs.translated: Hello, what's the news?

dialogs.original: Most mighty sovereign, on the western coast    Rideth a puissant navy. To our shores    Throng many doubtful hollow-hearted friends,    Unarmed and unresolved to beat them back.    'Tis thought that Richmond is their admiral;    And there they hull, expecting but the aid    Of Buckingham to welcome them ashore.
dialogs.translated: Most mighty king, a powerful navy is sailing to our western coast. Many weak, unreliable allies of ours have gathered at the shore to meet the shipsbut they are unarmed and undecided about whether or not to fight them. It's thought that Richmond is the invading navy's admiral. Right now the ships are just drifting around offshore, waiting for Buckingham to welcome them to land.

dialogs.original: Some light-foot friend post to the duke of NorfolkRatcliffe, thyself, or Catesby. Where is he?
dialogs.translated: Send some speedy ally to the duke of Norfolk. You go yourself, Ratcliffeor Catesby. Where is Catesby?

dialogs.original: Here, my good lord.
dialogs.translated: Here, my good lord.

dialogs.original: Catesby, fly to the duke.
dialogs.translated: Catesby, hurry to the Duke of Buckingham.

dialogs.original: I will, my lord, with all convenient haste.
dialogs.translated: I will go as quickly as I can, my lord.

dialogs.original: Ratcliffe, come hither. Post to Salisbury.    When thou comst thither        [to CATESBY]    Dull, unmindful villain,    Why stayst thou here and gost not to the duke?
dialogs.translated: Ratcliffe, come here. Ride quickly to Salisbury. When you get there

dialogs.original: First, mighty liege, tell me your Highness' pleasure,What from your Grace I shall deliver to him.
dialogs.translated: First, mighty King, tell me what your Highness wants, so I can deliver your message to him.

dialogs.original: O true, good Catesby. Bid him levy straightThe greatest strength and power that he can make And meet me suddenly at Salisbury.
dialogs.translated: Oh, true, good Catesby. Tell him to gather the largest army he can in a hurry, and meet me at Salisbury right away.

dialogs.original: I go.
dialogs.translated: I'm off.

dialogs.original: What, may it please you, shall I do at Salisbury?
dialogs.translated: And what would you like me to do at Salisbury?

dialogs.original: Why, what wouldst thou do there before I go?
dialogs.translated: Why, what would you do there before I arrive?

dialogs.original: Your Highness told me I should post before.
dialogs.translated: Your Highness just told me that I should hurry there.

dialogs.original: My mind is changed.
dialogs.translated: I've changed my mind.

dialogs.original: Stanley, what news with you?
dialogs.translated: Stanley, what's the news?

dialogs.original: None good, my liege, to please you with the hearing,Nor none so bad but well may be reported.
dialogs.translated: My lord, it's nothing so good that it will please you to hear it, but nothing so bad that I can't report it.

dialogs.original: Hoyday, a riddle! Neither good nor bad.    What needst thou run so many mile about    When thou mayst tell thy tale the nearest way?    Once more, what news?
dialogs.translated: Aha, a riddle! Neither good nor bad. Why do you need to run in such wide circles when you can get straight to the point with your story? I'll ask you again: what's the news?

dialogs.original: Richmond is on the seas.
dialogs.translated: Richmond is on the seas.

dialogs.original: There let him sink, and be the seas on him!White-livered runagate, what doth he there?
dialogs.translated: Let him sink there, so the seas will be on him! The cowardly rebel, what is he doing there?

dialogs.original: I know not, mighty sovereign, but by guess.
dialogs.translated: I don't know, mighty king. I can only guess.

dialogs.original: Well, as you guess?
dialogs.translated: Well, what do you guess?

dialogs.original: Stirred up by Dorset, Buckingham, and Morton,He makes for England, here to claim the crown.
dialogs.translated: That he's been stirred up by Dorset, Buckingham, and Morton, and now he's coming to England to claim the crown.

dialogs.original: Is the chair empty? Is the sword unswayed?    Is the king dead, the empire unpossessed?    What heir of York is there alive but we?    And who is Englands king but great Yorks heir?    Then tell me, what makes he upon the seas?
dialogs.translated: Is the throne empty? Does the royal sword have no owner? Is the king dead, the kingdom dispossessed? What living heir of the York family is there but me? And who can be England's king but great York's heir? So tell me, what is he doing at sea?

dialogs.original: Unless for that, my liege, I cannot guess.
dialogs.translated: Unless it's for that then I cannot guess, my lord.

dialogs.original: Unless for that he comes to be your liege, You cannot guess wherefore the Welshman comes.Thou wilt revolt and fly to him, I fear.
dialogs.translated: Unless he's coming to be your new king, you can't guess why that Welshman Richmond is coming? You will rebel and join him, I fear.

dialogs.original: No, my good lord. Therefore mistrust me not.
dialogs.translated: No, my good lord. Don't distrust me.

dialogs.original: Where is thy power, then, to beat him back?    Where be thy tenants and thy followers?    Are they not now upon the western shore,    Safe-conducting the rebels from their ships?
dialogs.translated: Where is your army, then, to beat him back? Where are your tenants and your followers? Aren't they on the western shore right now, helping his rebels disembark safely from their ships?

dialogs.original: No, my good lord. My friends are in the north.
dialogs.translated: No, my good lord. My friends are in the north.

dialogs.original: Cold friends to me. What do they in the northWhen they should serve their sovereign in the west?
dialogs.translated: Then they're cold friends to me. What are they doing in the north when they should be serving their king in the west?

dialogs.original: They have not been commanded, mighty king.    Pleaseth your Majesty to give me leave,    Ill muster up my friends and meet your Grace    Where and what time your Majesty shall please.
dialogs.translated: They haven't been commanded to do so, mighty king. If it would please your Majesty, I'll gather up my friends and meet your Grace wherever and whenever your Majesty wants.

dialogs.original: Ay, thou wouldst be gone to join with Richmond,But Ill not trust thee.
dialogs.translated: Yes, you want to leave so you can join Richmond. But I won't trust you.

dialogs.original: Most mighty sovereign,You have no cause to hold my friendship doubtful.I never was nor never will be false.
dialogs.translated: Most mighty king, you have no reason to doubt my friendship. I never have been false, and never will be.

dialogs.original: Go then and muster men, but leave behindYour son George Stanley. Look your heart be firm. Or else his heads assurance is but frail.
dialogs.translated: Go then and get your men, but leave behind your son, George Stanley. Make sure your loyalty stays firm, or else he has a good chance of losing his head.

dialogs.original: So deal with him as I prove true to you.
dialogs.translated: So treat him as well as my faithfulnes deserves.

dialogs.original: My gracious sovereign, now in Devonshire,    As I by friends am well advertisèd,    Sir Edward Courtney and the haughty prelate,    Bishop of Exeter, his elder brother,    With many more confederates are in arms.
dialogs.translated: My gracious king, my friends have informed me that Sir Edward Courtney and his elder brotherthe arrogant Bishop of Exeterare now in Devonshire with an army.

dialogs.original: In Kent, my liege, the Guilfords are in arms,And every hour more competitorsFlock to the rebels, and their power grows strong.
dialogs.translated: My lord, Buckingham's supportersthe Guilfordsare armed and gathering in Kent. Every hour more men flock to join the rebels, and their army grows strong.

dialogs.original: My lord, the army of great Buckingham
dialogs.translated: My lord, great Buckingham's army

dialogs.original: Out on you, owls! Nothing but songs of death.  [he striketh him]  There, take thou that till thou bring better news.
dialogs.translated: Enough, you owls! All I hear are songs of death. [He strikes the THIRD MESSENGER] There, take that until you bring me better news.

dialogs.original: The news I have to tell your Majesty    Is that by sudden floods and fall of waters    Buckinghams army is dispersed and scattered,    And he himself wandered away alone,    No man knows whither.
dialogs.translated: The news I have to tell your Majesty is that sudden floods and heavy rains have dispersed and scattered Buckingham's army. Buckingham himself has wandered away alone, though no one knows where.

dialogs.original: I cry thee mercy.    There is my purse to cure that blow of thine.     [he gives money]     Hath any well-advisèd friend proclaimed    Reward to him that brings the traitor in?
dialogs.translated: I beg your pardon. Here's some money to cure that blow I gave you. [He gives money] Has any quick-thinking friend of mine offered a reward to whoever brings that traitor in?

dialogs.original: Such proclamation hath been made, my lord.
dialogs.translated: Yes, that proclamation has been made, my lord.

dialogs.original: Sir Thomas Lovell and Lord Marquess Dorset,    'Tis said, my liege, in Yorkshire are in arms.    But this good comfort bring I to your Highness:    The Breton navy is dispersed by tempest.    Richmond, in Dorsetshire, sent out a boat    Unto the shore to ask those on the banks    If they were his assistants, yea or no   Who answered him they came from Buckingham    Upon his party. He, mistrusting them,    Hoisted sail and made his course for Brittany.
dialogs.translated: It's reported that Sir Thomas Lovell and the Lord Marquess of Dorset are gathering an army in Yorkshire. But I bring your Highness this comfort: Richmond's navy has been dispersed by a storm. At Dorsetshire, Richmond sent a boat to shore to ask the men on the banks if they were his allies. They answered that they were with Buckingham. Richmond didn't trust them, and he hoisted sail and returned to Brittany.

dialogs.original: March on, march on, since we are up in arms,If not to fight with foreign enemies,Yet to beat down these rebels here at home.
dialogs.translated: March on, march on, since we're already prepared for battle. Even if we don't have to fight foreign enemies, we'll still beat down these rebels here at home.

dialogs.original: My liege, the duke of Buckingham is taken.    That is the best news.   That the earl of Richmond    Is with a mighty power landed at Milford,    Is colder tidings, yet they must be told.
dialogs.translated: My lord, the Duke of Buckingham has been captured. That's the best news. There's worse, but it must be told: The Earl of Richmond has landed at Milford with a mighty army.

dialogs.original: Away towards Salisbury! While we reason here,    A royal battle might be won and lost.    Someone take order Buckingham be brought    To Salisbury. The rest march on with me.
dialogs.translated: We must go away towards Salisbury! While we talk here, a royal battle might be won and lost. Someone deliver the order that Buckingham should be brought to Salisbury. The rest of you, march on with me.
